metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 260 of 1953 and Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1954

facts.text: Appellant contractor entered into a contract with the Dominion of India through Additional Chief Engineer of CPWD on 1-11-1945 for supply of 2-1/2 crores of pucca bricks to be delivered at kiln site according to schedule: 30 lacs by 25-1-46, 50 lacs by 25-2-46, 55 lacs by 25-3-46, 55 lacs by 25-4-46, 60 lacs by 25-5-46.
Disputes arose and were referred to Superintending Engineer under Clause 14 on 21-1-1949; award given on 8-5-1949.
Award filed in Court of Subordinate Judge, Dhanbad; contractor prayed for decree in terms of award; registered as suit under s.20 Arbitration Act; decree passed on 18-3-1950 in favour of contractor.
Union of India (replacing Dominion) filed objections under s.30 Arbitration Act seeking to set aside, modify or remit award; appealed to High Court of Patna which allowed appeal in part on 11-5-1951.

Contractor had to prepare katcha (unbaked) bricks in advance; CPWD duty to remove baked bricks promptly; CPWD failed to remove, causing jam and accumulation of 88 lacs katcha bricks destroyed by rain.
Clause 6 of agreement: 'The department will not entertain any claim for idle labour or for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever.'
Arbitrator awarded Rs.64,075 under claim 5 (katcha bricks) holding Clause 6 not absolving department from contractual obligations.

Claim 8: Rs.51,495 for additional wages to coolies due to non-supply of ration and cloth; rationing in locality, contractor employed 1800 coolies from far off, department promised supply; arbitrator awarded Rs.40,000 holding implied obligation.
Claim 17: Interest Rs.27,665 at 6% for 16 months from 1-1-1948; arbitrator awarded Rs.17,363 on awarded amounts holding reasonable.
Awards under other heads: Rs.11,744-11-0 under claim 4 for extra labour stacking bricks; Rs.15,500 under claim 13 for levelling land.

In second appeal (CA 12/1954): Similar contract on 1-11-1945; same arbitrator, award 1-5-1949; disputes on claims 4 (rations/cloth Rs.51,495, awarded Rs.30,000) and 17 (interest Rs.27,665, awarded Rs.9,954).
Tender submitted 25-9-1945; accepted 1-11-1945; contractor warned Executive Engineer 9-11-1945 about rations; contract signed 22-11-1945 without ration clause.
Sindri was rationed area; CPWD arranged rations for own employees via local Civil Supply Authorities.

legal_issues.text: Whether arbitrator erred in law by awarding on claim 5 (katcha bricks) ignoring Clause 6, and whether such error apparent on face of award allowing court interference under s.16(1)(c) Arbitration Act.
Whether specific question of law (construction of Clause 6) was referred to arbitrator, ousting court jurisdiction.
Whether arbitrator erred in awarding on claim 8 (rations/cloth) based on implied or collateral contract.
Whether arbitrator had power to award interest under claim 17.

petitioner_arguments.text: Loss of 88 lacs katcha bricks due to department's failure to lift quota; Clause 6 inapplicable as department at fault and covers damage not destruction.
Department promised ration supply pre-contract; circumstantial evidence shows mutual understanding; moral and legal liability.
Interest due as claims should have been settled by 31-12-1947; blocked funds forced borrowing.

respondent_arguments.text: Katcha bricks not part of contract; loss remote; Clause 6 expressly excludes liability for damage to unburnt bricks.
No promise or clause for rations; contract signed without it; government bound only by signed contracts.

court_reasoning.text: Arbitrator wrong in law on claim 5: Clause 6 expressly excludes liability for damage to unburnt bricks; parties contemplated such risk; contractor must mitigate under s.73; no specific reference of law question.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Error of law apparent on face of award; courts can interfere unless specific question of law referred.

court_reasoning.text: No specific reference of Clause 6 construction; incidental argument in proceedings insufficient to oust court jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reference requires agreement by both sides or court order under s.20(4).

court_reasoning.text: No implied or collateral contract for rations: facts show contractor signed without assent; error to infer from contentions; separate from written contract, outside arbitration clause.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government bound only by signed contracts; rationing provincial matter.

court_reasoning.text: No power to award interest: claims unliquidated; Interest Act conditions not met; arbitrator not court under CPC s.34.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interest not payable by law otherwise.

holdings.text: Clause 6 relieves government of liability for katcha bricks damage; arbitrator's award set aside.
Courts retain jurisdiction to correct errors of law apparent on face of award unless specific question of law referred.
No implied or collateral obligation for rations/cloth; award set aside.
Arbitrator has no power to award pre-suit interest on unliquidated claims.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kelantan Government v. Duff Development Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Courts interfere if arbitrator acts illegally even on specifically referred law question.

precedents_cited.case_name: F. R. Absalom Ltd. v. Great Western (London) Garden Village Society
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles on when question of law is specifically referred vs. incidental.

precedents_cited.case_name: Champsey Bhara & Co. v. Jivraj Balloo Spinning and Weaving Co.
A. M. Mair & Co. v. Gordhandas Sagarmull
precedents_cited.relevance: Dispute must be defined and agreed for reference.
Arbitration clause confined to matters relating to contract; need defined dispute.
Wider language confined to revisional powers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Nagpur Ry. Co. v. Ruttanji Ramji
precedents_cited.relevance: Interest Act applies where not otherwise payable.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Objections to award; remit for reconsideration if error of law apparent; filing award as suit.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Mitigate loss; promises express and implied.

statutes_cited.name: Interest Act, 1839
statutes_cited.relevance: Conditions for awarding interest on debts.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Interest from suit date; does not apply to arbitrators.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed contractor's appeals, upholding High Court's decision to set aside arbitrator's awards on disputed claims 5,8,17 (first appeal) and 4,17 (second appeal) for errors of law apparent on face of award.

key_quotes.text: "An arbitrator is not a conciliator and cannot ignore the law or misapply it in order to do what he thinks is just and reasonable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle on arbitrator bound by law.

key_quotes.text: "The department will not entertain any claim for idle labour or for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Exact terms of Clause 6 excluding liability.

key_quotes.text: "If a question of law is specifically referred... then the Courts will not interfere."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits on court interference with award.
